title: 103_s1871
content: SECTION 1. FINDINGS AND PURPOSES. The Congress finds that the New Bedford National Historic Landmark District and associated historic sites, including the Schooner Ernestina, are significant for illustrating the history of whaling in the United States. New Bedford was a key city in the 19th-century whaling industry, with architectural features and museum collections that showcase this period's importance. These historic resources offer opportunities to understand the economic, social, and environmental impact of the whaling industry in the United States. The New Bedford Whaling National Historical Park aims to preserve and interpret resources related to whaling history, collaborate with local organizations, and provide educational opportunities for the public. SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS. The term "park" refers to the New Bedford Whaling National Historical Park, and the term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The New Bedford Whaling National Historical Park is established to preserve districts, structures, and relics associated with the history of whaling in America. The boundaries of the park are defined by a specific map and include the New Bedford National Historic Landmark District. The Bedford Landing Waterfront Historic District, listed in the National Register of Historic Places, includes the National Historic Landmark Schooner Ernestina. Other areas within the New Bedford National Historic Landmark District are also designated for preservation and interpretation by the Secretary. The Bedford Landing Waterfront Historic District, listed in the National Register of Historic Places, includes various sites for interpretation and preservation such as the southwest corner of the State Pier, Waterfront Park, Rotch-Jones-Duff House and Garden Museum, Wharfinger Building, and Bourne Counting House. The administration of the park is outlined in Section 4. The park shall be administered by the Secretary in accordance with applicable laws, including the National Park Service Act. The Secretary may enter into cooperative agreements for park activities and acquire property and services. The Secretary may accept donated funds, property, and services to carry out the park administration in New Bedford, Massachusetts. The Secretary must submit a general management plan for the park to the Senate and House committees within two years of this Act's enactment. The plan must comply with relevant laws. Additionally, funds necessary to implement this Act are authorized to be appropriated.
